item.title: an awesome read
item.content:encoded: took me a while to read this article but it's been like reading an adventure book. thanks.

item.title: Thanks indeed
item.content:encoded:
Just today I was in a meeting in a German administrative office regarding the integration of many different systems in the GIS subculture. It's much like you described in that one project at the cement factory with different parties involved. Over the past few years I also managed to get people which were previously a little hostile (not really hostile, but not cooperative either) to be in our boat to get things done. This article just got me thinking, perhaps my stance of being just a good coder may have to change over time, and I'll finally have to master people skills…

Then I read about your demise (I hope Internet access is good in heaven), and can just thank you for this beautiful writeup regarding 'Enterprise' software work to get Things Done. I'm a few decades younger, but I can absolutely relate to you. I've made most of the mistakes you made (caring too much about technology and not realizing 'getting rich quick' opportunities), but IMHO it's just the way we are. Kudos! And a good afterlife!

If anyone related/knowing this man reads this, all I can say is that this article (the 'probably my last article' article also moved me) is one that is for me so obviously honest, I find it is one of the best. That he found the time to write this up is really touching me and I think many others!

item.title: Thanks a lot
item.content:encoded:
It took me all weekend to read this and I want to say thank you for sharing your experiences.
And I want to ask your permission to use one sentence from your post as my new forum signature - as a tribute to you and your writings.

Thanks again!

item.title: Wonderful
item.content:encoded:
Thanks for continuing to write for us Pieter. You'll be happy or horrified to know that Xitami is still running in production. One of my favorite pieces of software ever. And while I've never had to invoke your name in an appeal to authority, I always knew you were out there whenever I wrote a code generator.

And I'll take a quiet walk down memory lane myself, about past code and people, and life's lessons learned.

Warmest regards, always.

P.S. Where you say "We were able to increase performance from 150K messages/second to 600 messages/second.", the numbers seem askew. A missing K perhaps?

item.title: Thank you.
item.content:encoded:
Thank you, from all the bright-eyed naifs never expecting the crush of corporate politics.
Thank you, from all the huddled masses toiling in the cubicle farms.
Thank you, from the war-grizzled veterans, nodding at every shared experience.

This was a seminal piece, and I hope it gets shared to all heck.

item.title: Amazing Story
item.content:encoded: Can't believe I've been two decades in the industry and was hitherto unaware of your work (I sort of vaguely knew your name). Anyway, there's not much I can say that that does it justice, but it was truly an inspirational and riveting memoir whose lessons I will carry with me and hopefully put to some use! Thank you.

item.title: Some great lessons in life!
item.content:encoded:
Hi Pieter, lots of interesting memories there, there was a lot on your side I wasn't aware of, particularly with your family at the time, my condolences.

As someone who was there at the time (as you know in JPMC and working with "John") I can corroborate everything you said. I would however say, in John's defence, that he never said anything bad about you and always respected and spoke highly of you in private. When I first saw the spec (and met you) it was very clearly yours, John had the vision and the position at the bank to make it happen. You very clearly implemented that vision, not just the spec but the first and only version JPMC ever used.
Putting AMQP aside you point out a lot of life lessons, some I've learnt in similar ways, some I'm struggling with now, hearing them from you will help me navigate though the crap.
It was great spending an evening with you drinking beer about a year ago, if you're still allowed to drink have one from me and thanks for writing this.

-John-

item.title: very interesting and at times instructive essay
item.content:encoded:
I've spent three evenings reading this (only to find now that essay was quite updated. Must re-read!) and enjoyed every moment. Felt sorry for your family for 2005 tragedy and being occupied by work at that time, laughed out loud in the room at the project finished under budget and became a bit sad at shitty people story. Those are some familiar and right lessons there. I'm hooked to read your books now (and sad there won't be any new :'( )

I'm only 9 years in IT and learned the issue of politics, liars and social climbers the hard way and early in my career. I actually like the fact I learned it soon. I'm currently recovering from yet another toxic environment, struggling with insomnia, anxiety (, depression?) and fatigue.

I'll quote this part in my (possible) future presentations:

"It doesn't matter how good the design, when there are unresolved problems in the organization.

And so gradually I shifted from technical architect to social architect. From caring about technical designs to caring about people and the psychology that drives them. Because in the end, this is what seems to make the difference between a working project and a failure"

Same said by Jerry Weinberg - "No matter how it looks at first, it's always a people problem". Same learned from Jim Coplien, my blue pill scrum teacher and the organizational patterns guy, a lot Scrum's rules come from different failure and success stories. The team sizes, the relative estimation, standups etc. Then there's negotiation techniques. The latter seem quite important, especially given that a lot of us geeks are closed and humble people. I recently tweeted that I'd take away computers from first semester Computer Science students and would teach them how to talk, clarify and argue with people, only then learn to code. We probably would be so much better off!

I wanted to become a doctor in high school, but became as I see it a software and software projects doctor. I think I'll continue this way (until I get a stroke or heart attack (or have enough money to retire early and start writing books)), because it seems there are not so many people in teams who see dysfunctions, have the guts to name them and to propose ideas. Someone has to do it, but needs to indeed set limits and not burn ones self.

Thank you, it was a influential read!

Good times, and thanks for them.
